title: Exhibition Checklist
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section body" id="body">After seeing Theodore Roussel’s watercolor The Thames Embankment, Chelsea at a London gallery in 1885, the already well-established James McNeill Whistler requested an introduction to the younger artist. Their meeting sparked more than a decade of professional collaboration that included side-by-side working sessions and camaraderie in both public and private settings. As a result of such communal creativity, Whistler, Roussel, and their artistic circle made remarkable technical and aesthetic developments in lithography and color etching.

While museums including the Art Institute of Chicago have long celebrated Whistler’s many-faceted career, much less attention has been given to Roussel and indeed to the larger community of artists and models with whom both Roussel and Whistler worked. This exhibition considers the nature of collaboration in late nineteenth-century London through the lens of the intertwining lives and creative projects of these two artists.

As part of the larger etching revival, which promoted a reconsideration of etching as a form of fine art, Whistler implemented a number of technical strategies to enhance the unique status of individual impressions of his prints. These included developing a final image through a progressive series of states; selectively wiping the plate prior to printing an impression; and trimming intaglio prints to their plate marks to call the viewer’s attention to the art works rather than the margins around them (leaving only a tab for the artist’s signature). Roussel adopted all of these practices, and a number of his intaglio prints demonstrate his familiarity with Whistler’s methods while others show his separate exploration of tonal techniques like aquatint and softground.

In transfer lithography, the artist creates a design in lithographic crayon on specially coated paper instead of directly on the lithographic stone. The drawing is then transferred to the stone, and as a result, the artist can maintain the spontaneity of the original in the realized print. Whistler introduced Roussel to transfer lithography, and a selection of their finished work as well as several surviving untransferred drawings are on display here.

To create color effects in their printing, Roussel and Whistler explored different technical approaches. Color could be introduced through multiple printing matrices (one lithographic stone for each color present, as in Whistler’s Yellow House) or through direct application of colored inks to a single etching plate (as in Roussel’s Sea at Bognor). Both artists gave careful consideration to their ink colors, experimenting with different formulae and combinations in numerous trial proofs. Roussel carried his investigations further, developing an innovative technique using textile plates and stencils (as exemplified by L’oublié).

Whistler, who first created frame designs for his paintings, developed distinctive white frames with linear decoration for his etchings and lithographs. Clearly influenced by the older artist, Roussel conceived more elaborate schemes in which he affixed etched designs to frame moldings. This approach to framing his prints extended beyond the decoration of the frame itself to include printed mounts, which served as backdrops for his color prints. The resulting ensembles incorporated printed elements in every component—art object, mount, and frame.

Born in France, Theodore Roussel relocated to England in the 1870s, where he participated in the fields of painting and the graphic arts. As the works on display amply demonstrate, Roussel invested considerable artistic energy in an exploration of the technical capabilities of printmaking, pushing the limits of visual expression through manipulations of intaglio processes, experimental color printing, and frame design. While a participant in the social and intellectual circles of late nineteenth-century London, Roussel was fundamentally an introspective figure, preferring sustained and solitary explorations to the cultivation of a public persona. His elegant and thoughtful work, therefore, is still gaining recognition and acclaim.

In addition to portraying members of their own families, Whistler and Roussel also employed professional models. Another point of connection between these two artists—as well as their peers—is their affiliation with some of the same models, whose likenesses are displayed in this group of works.

London of the late nineteenth century was a city dense with private clubs of many different stripes. These clubs, as well as restaurants and various exhibiting societies, provided artists with many venues for social interaction. As someone who avoided dining alone, Whistler frequented the various clubs to which he belonged. Roussel was a member of some of the same institutions, as were a great many of their literary and artistic colleagues. These were spaces where intellectual questions could be posed and creative problems could be solved—not entirely in spite of dinner also being served.

The working relationship that Whistler and Roussel maintained for over a decade serves as one example of the artistic collaboration that characterized creative life in late nineteenth-century London and Paris. The works in this gallery reflect the reach of the artistic communities to which both artists belonged before and after the time of their mutual acquaintance. The overlapping interests in similar subjects and similar technical experimental evident in these objects manifest the active circulation of ideas among these creative peers.

From November 1898 through February 1899, the South Kensington Museum (now called the Victoria and Albert Museum) mounted an exhibition devoted to the art of lithography to celebrate the centenary of the technique’s invention. This monumental project, which included over 2,000 lithographs, reflected the widespread artistic enthusiasm for this technique as an expressive medium. Alongside many friends and contemporaries, Whistler and Roussel both participated in this exhibition.

Under the tutelage of Frank Duveneck, a group of American students traveled in 1880 from Munich to Venice to continue their artistic training. Shortly after their arrival, they encountered Whistler, who was there to create his now famous series of Venice etchings. Duveneck, his students, and the more renowned Whistler soon joined forces, residing in the same location, sharing printmaking equipment and materials, and exchanging ideas about subject matter and specific printing techniques such as the selective wiping of their copper printing plates.

Beyond his prolific work as a painter, printmaker, draftsman, and interior designer, Whistler attained celebrity status through his mannered style of self-presentation and lust for media attention. His contemporaries responded by creating scores of portraits, some reverent and others within the caricature tradition. As early as 1918, only fifteen years after Whistler’s death, a scholarly study was published that listed over 260 known portraits of Whistler. This gallery contains a sample of those works.

A selection of letters, books, and pamphlets are included in the exhibition. In particular, examples of the correspondence between Whistler and Roussel convey the tenor of their relationship through everyday messages about meeting times and places and more personal expressions of artistic connection and condolence.

1.2 James McNeill Whistler (American, 1834–1903). Nocturne: Blue and Gold—Southampton Water, 1872. Oil on canvas; 505 × 760 mm. YMSM 117. The Art Institute of Chicago, Stickney Fund, 1900.52.

1.7 James McNeill Whistler (American, 1834–1903). Carlyle’s Sweetstuff Shop, 1885/89. Oil on panel; 130 × 214 mm (sight). YMSM 375. Terra Foundation for American Art, Daniel J. Terra Collection, 1992.147.

1.4 James McNeill Whistler (American, 1834–1903). Fish Shop, Chelsea, 1886. Etching and drypoint with foul biting and plate tone in dark brown on ivory laid paper; 140 × 217 mm (image, trimmed within plate mark), 143 × 217 mm (sheet, with signature tab). G 267 I/II; K 264 I/II. The Art Institute of Chicago, Clarence Buckingham Collection, 1938.1883.

1.5 Theodore Roussel (English, born France, 1847–1926). The Little Fish Shop, Chelsea Embankment, 1888–89. Etching in black on cream Japanese paper; 120 × 80 mm (plate), 165 × 118 mm (sheet). H 25. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Meg and Mark Hausberg, 2011.461.

1.6 James McNeill Whistler (American, 1834–1903). Maunder’s Fish Shop, Chelsea, 1890. Transfer lithograph in black on cream laid paper; 190 × 170 mm (image), 332 × 200 mm (sheet). C 37 II/II. The Art Institute of Chicago, bequest of Bryan Lathrop, 1917.561.

1.9 James McNeill Whistler (American, 1834–1903). A Chelsea Shop, 1894/95. Oil on panel; 127 × 214 mm (sight). YMSM 448. Terra Foundation for American Art, Daniel J. Terra Collection, 1992.148.

1.8 Theodore Roussel (English, born France, 1847–1926). Rotten Row, Hyde Park, c. 1889. Oil on panel; 127 × 220 mm (sight). Private collection.

Etching and drypoint in black, with selective wiping of plate tone, on ivory laid paper; 297 × 200 mm (image, trimmed within plate mark); 307 × 201 mm (sheet, with signature tab). G 200 II/XII; K 202 I/IX. The Art Institute of Chicago, Clarence Buckingham Collection, 1938.1910.

G 200 XI/XII; K 202 VIII/IX. The Art Institute of Chicago, Bryan Lathrop Collection, 1934.593.

2.5 James McNeill Whistler (American, 1834–1903). Drury Lane, 1880/81. Etching with foul biting in black on cream laid paper; 162 × 102 mm (image, trimmed within plate mark); 168 × 102 mm (sheet, with signature tab). G 243; K 237. The Art Institute of Chicago, bequest of Bryan Lathrop, 1917.470.

2.6 James McNeill Whistler (American, 1834–1903) Drury Lane, 1880/81. Cancelled copper plate; 164 × 103 mm. G 243; K 237. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Walter S. Brewster, 1933.694.

Etching and drypoint in brown, with selective wiping of plate tone, on cream Japanese paper; 342 × 221 mm (plate), 421 × 272 mm (sheet). H 34 V/V. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Meg and Mark Hausberg, 2011.469.

2.9 Emile Bayard (French, 1868–1937). La cellulotypie, c. 1902. Lithograph in blue on tan wove paper, book; 253 × 170 × 100 mm. The Art Institute of Chicago, Ryerson and Burnham Libraries.

2.10 Theodore Roussel (English, born France, 1847–1926). Buoyant Sea, 1919. Soft ground etching in black on cream Japanese paper; 53 × 177 mm (plate), 109 × 213 mm (sheet). H 116 III/III. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Meg and Mark Hausberg, 2011.544.

2.11 Theodore Roussel (English, born France, 1847–1926). Trial Plate for Nine O’Clock A.M., 1919–20. Gelatin plate with incised lines and traces of red ink; 176 × 122 mm. H 120. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Meg and Mark Hausberg, 2015.22.

2.12 Theodore Roussel (English, born France, 1847–1926). Nine O’Clock A.M., 1919–20. Drypoint in black on cream wove paper; 176 × 121 mm (plate), 244 × 189 mm (sheet). H 120 V/V. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Meg and Mark Hausberg, 2011.545.

2.7 Theodore Roussel (English, born France, 1847–1926). The Steam Launch, Chelsea Embankment, 1888/89. Etching in black on ivory laid paper; 76 × 118 mm (image); 82 × 121 mm (plate); 88 × 121 mm (sheet). H 18. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Meg and Mark Hausberg, 2011.454.

3.1 James McNeill Whistler (American, 1834–1903). Two Sketches, 1878/79. Lithographic crayon and brush and tusche on coarse-grained transfer paper; 262 × 179 mm. C vol. 1,p. 500, I.I; M 677. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of the Crown Family in honor of James N. Wood, 2004.674.

3.2 Theodore Roussel (English, born France, 1847–1926). Standing Figure in a Chinese Gown, 1890–94. Lithographic crayon on fine-grained transfer paper; 322 × 244 mm. H A.III. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Meg and Mark Hausberg, 2011.617.

3.3 James McNeill Whistler (American, 1834–1903). Draped Figure, Reclining, 1892. Color transfer lithograph from five stones on ivory laid paper; 180 × 258 mm (image), 187 × 288 mm (sheet). C 56 II/II. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of the Crown Family in honor of James N. Wood, 2004.583.

3.4 James McNeill Whistler (American, 1834–1903). Reclining Draped Figure, 1893. C VII (p. 506); M 1305. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Walter S. Brewster, 1933.213.

3.5 Édouard Duchâtel (French, 1893–1907). Traité de lithographie artistique, 1893. Lithograph in black on gray wove paper, book; 330 × 255 × 20 mm. The Art Institute of Chicago, Ryerson and Burnham Libraries.

4.1 James McNeill Whistler (American, 1834–1903). Corte del Paradiso, 1880. Pastel and black chalk on brown wove paper with fibrous inclusions; 301 × 149 mm. M 784. The Art Institute of Chicago, Walter Aitken, Margaret Day Blake, Harold Joachim Memorial, Celia and David Hilliard, Julius Lewis, and Sara R. Shorey endowments; Sandra L. Grung Fund; restricted gifts of William Vance and Pamela Kelley Armour; through prior acquisitions of Katherine Kuh, 2002.679.

4.2 James McNeill Whistler (American, 1834–1903). Yellow House, Lannion, 1893. Color transfer lithograph with scraping, from five stones on cream Japanese paper; 242 × 162 mm (image), 319 × 204 mm (sheet). C 67 II/III. The Art Institute of Chicago, the Charles Deering Collection, 1927.5849.

4.3 James McNeill Whistler (American, 1834–1903). Yellow House, Lannion, 1893. Color transfer lithograph, with scraping, from six stones on ivory laid paper; 242 × 162 mm (image), 367 × 242 mm (sheet). C 67 III/III. The Art Institute of Chicago, Bryan Lathrop Collection, 1934.527.

4.4 Theodore Roussel (English, born France, 1847–1926). The Sea at Bognor, 1895. Soft ground etching in black on ivory laid paper; 98 × 148 mm (plate), 110 × 160 mm (sheet). H 147 III/III. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Meg and Mark Hausberg, 2011.573.1.

4.5 Theodore Roussel (English, born France, 1847–1926). The Sea at Bognor, 1895. Color soft ground etching, inked à la poupée, on ivory laid paper; 75 × 141 mm (image, trimmed within plate mark); 100 × 151 mm (sheet). H 147 II/III. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Meg and Mark Hausberg, 2011.573.2.

4.6 Theodore Roussel (English, born France, 1847–1926). The Sea at Bognor, 1895. Color soft ground etching, inked à la poupée, on ivory laid paper; 45 × 140 mm (image, plate mark only partially visible); 103 × 153 mm (sheet). H 147 II/III. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Meg and Mark Hausberg, 2011.573.7.

4.7 Theodore Roussel (English, born France, 1847–1926). The Sea at Bognor, 1895. Color monotype on ivory laid paper; 52 × 143 mm (image, plate mark only partially visible); 105 × 152 mm (sheet). H 147 II/III. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Meg and Mark Hausberg, 2011.573.8.

4.9 Theodore Roussel (English, born France, 1847–1926). The Sea at Bognor, 1895. Color soft ground etching, inked à la poupée, with inkless intaglio on ivory laid paper; 93 × 140 mm (image/sheet, plate mark not visible). H 147 II/III. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Meg and Mark Hausberg, 2011.573.9.

4.8 Theodore Roussel (English, born France, 1847–1926). The Sea at Bognor, 1895. Color soft ground etching, inked à la poupée, on ivory laid paper; 100 × 149 mm (plate), 128 × 206 mm (sheet). H 147 II/III. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Meg and Mark Hausberg, 2011.573.11.

4.10 Theodore Roussel (English, born France, 1847–1926). L’oublié, 1920–22. Color print from thirteen textile plates, with stencil, on ivory wove paper; 142 × 209 mm (image), 215 × 302 mm (sheet). H 181. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Meg and Mark Hausberg, 2011.615.

4.11 Theodore Roussel (English, born France, 1847–1926). Sketch for L’oubilé, 1920/22. Gouache on cream laid paper, discolored to tan; 75 × 174 mm. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Meg and Mark Hausberg, 2011.622.

4.12 Theodore Roussel (English, born France, 1847–1926). The Little Cloud, 1923. Color print from three textile plates on off-white wove paper; 51 × 78 mm (image), 127 × 143 mm (sheet). H 184. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Meg and Mark Hausberg, 2011.616.

Print, H 143; mount, H 168a; frame, H 162a. Private collection.

The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Meg and Mark Hausberg, 2011.600.

5.10 Theodore Roussel (English, born France, 1847–1926). Beginning of a Frame Design, 1889/1908. Brush and black ink on cream laid paper, joined and laid down onto wood frame, and varnished; 370 × 344 × 20 mm. Private collection.

5.11 Theodore Roussel (English, born France, 1847–1926). Design for a Frame, 1899–1908. Pen and brush and black ink, with graphite and traces of white gouache on semi-transparent yellowish brown wove paper; 266 × 650 mm. H A.V. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Meg and Mark Hausberg, 2011.619.

5.12 Theodore Roussel (English, born France, 1847–1926). Phaeton Pattern Frame (Early Trial), 1907/08. Etching in black, with additions in pen and black ink, on ivory laid paper, joined and laid down onto wood frame, and varnished; 473 × 456 × 20 mm. H 166 I/III. Private collection.

5.13 Theodore Roussel (English, born France, 1847–1926). Untitled Drawing for Frame Cartouche (Plant Motif), 1899/1908. Brush and black ink on semitransparent tan wove paper; 92 × 201 mm. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Meg and Mark Hausberg, 2011.624.1.

5.14 Theodore Roussel (English, born France, 1847–1926). Untitled Drawing for Frame Cartouche (Salamander), 1899/1908. Brush and black ink, gold metallic ink, and watercolor on semi-transparent tan wove paper; 83 × 170 mm. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Meg and Mark Hausberg, 2011.624.2.

5.15 Theodore Roussel (English, born France, 1847–1926). Phaeton Pattern Frame, 1907/08. Etching in black on ivory laid paper, joined and laid down onto wood frame, and varnished; 283 × 407 × 22 mm. H 166 III/III. Collection of David and Toni Mathis.

5.16 Theodore Roussel (English, born France, 1847–1926). Jupiter and Alcmene Medallion, Sketch for Decoration of a Frame, 1907–08. Etching in black on cream laid paper; 53 × 82 mm (plate), 57 × 82 mm (sheet). H 74. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Meg and Mark Hausberg, 2011.507.

5.17 Theodore Roussel (English, born France, 1847–1926). Jupiter and Alcmene and Nymphs and Satyrs on a Frieze Medallion, Study for Decoration of a Frame, 1907–08. Etching and soft ground in black on cream laid paper; 50 × 80 mm (plate), 55 × 80 mm (sheet). H 75 III/III. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Meg and Mark Hausberg, 2011.508.

Etching, soft ground, and aquatint in black on cream wove imitation Japanese paper; 452 × 348 mm (plate), 482 × 369 mm (sheet). H 45 VII/IX. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Meg and Mark Hausberg, 2011.480.

6.10 Unknown artist (late 19th century). Bottle-Necked Vase with Images of Warriors, 19th century. Stoneware with applied animal masks and lizard-like creatures; painted in overglaze enamels and iron brown; 290 × 193 mm. Private collection.

6.11 Theodore Roussel (English, born France, 1847–1926). Last Poppies, 1897. Etching and soft ground in black on ivory wove paper; 78 × 67 mm (image, trimmed within plate mark); 82 × 67 mm (sheet, with signature tab). H 150. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Meg and Mark Hausberg, 2011.580.

6.12 Theodore Roussel (English, born France, 1847–1926). Last Poppies, 1897. Etching and soft ground in dark reddish brown on bluish ivory laid paper; 79 × 68 mm (plate), 105 × 94 mm (sheet). H 150. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Meg and Mark Hausberg, 2011.581.

The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Meg and Mark Hausberg, 2011.584.

The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Meg and Mark Hausberg, 2011.488. \* Exhibited in Phaeton Pattern Frame, 1907/08.

Etching with plate tone in black on cream Japanese paper; 190 × 222 mm (plate), 198 × 222 mm (sheet, with signature tab). H 70 XVI/XVI. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Meg and Mark Hausberg, 2011.504.

6.16 Theodore Roussel (English, born France, 1847–1926). Portrait of Marion Melville, c. 1906. Watercolor on off-white wove paper; 175 × 125 mm (sight). Private collection. \* Exhibited in Lily Pattern Frame, 1888/89.

6.17 Theodore Roussel (English, born France, 1847–1926). Dawn, 1912–13. Color etching, aquatint, soft ground, and drypoint on ivory wove paper; 670 × 313 mm (image, trimmed within plate mark); 706 × 350 mm (sheet). H 157. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Meg and Mark Hausberg, 2011.589.

6.18 Theodore Roussel (English, born France, 1847–1926). Moonrise in the New Forest, 1914 Color aquatint on ivory laid paper; 375 × 254 mm (image, trimmed within plate mark); 405 × 279 mm (sheet). H 158. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Meg and Mark Hausberg, 2011.593.

6.19 Harriet Selina Pettigrew (English, 1867–1953). Profile Portrait of Theodore Roussel, 1897/1907. Relief sculpture in bronze; 112 mm (diameter). Private collection.

6.20 Harriet Selina Pettigrew (English, 1867–1953). Profile Portrait of Frances Smithson Roussel, 1897/1907. Relief sculpture in bronze; 112 mm (diameter). Private collection.

7.1 James McNeill Whistler (American, 1834–1903). Finette, 1859. Etching and drypoint in black on ivory Japanese paper; 290 × 201 mm (plate), 386 × 264 mm (sheet). G 61 X/XIV; K 58 VII/X. The Art Institute of Chicago, Bryan Lathrop Collection, 1934.544.
